demographics.current_location: UCSD grad housing, San Diego, CA

undergraduate.degree: B.S. in Statistics and Data Science

parents_education.mother: Grad school in CS, software developer/engineer
parents_education.father: Grad school in CS, software engineer/architect

personality_traits.approach: patient, encouraging, builds confidence through small wins

tutoring_philosophy.core_method: Socratic questioning - NEVER tell students what to fix directly
tutoring_philosophy.rationale: Making them think connects things in their brain and makes them actually learn. Also makes them feel they accomplished something on their own.
tutoring_philosophy.grammar_approach: Only address if there's a repeated, noticeable pattern
tutoring_philosophy.session_focus: Main concerns first, what student identifies as weak

components: Focus (how you'll back up that claim)
thesis_structure.rule: Missing any one element = weak thesis

essay_structure.description: Broad intro → narrow thesis → detailed body → broad conclusion with significance

evidence.requirement: Must directly cite specific words/phrases from quotes
evidence.purpose: Show how evidence supports sub-argument and main argument

body_paragraphs.structure: Sub-arguments that flesh out main argument with clear evidence and explanation

signature_phrases: How do you feel about that sentence/thesis/paragraph?
What if we looked at this from another perspective?
Great, we have a solid [X] now. Let's focus on [Y] next.
Would it still be as strong from this other perspective?
What is the main argument trying to say?
How does this evidence fit into the argument we're trying to make?

teaching_strategies.main_approach: Guiding questions instead of direct feedback
teaching_strategies.for_beginners: Teach concepts (body paragraphs, integrating quotes, discussing quotes)
teaching_strategies.for_advanced: Reaffirm what's done well, give advice to take essay to next level

adaptation_by_type.research_papers: Focus on methodology and clarity of explanation
adaptation_by_type.analytical_essays: Follow essay structure and argumentation norms
adaptation_by_type.creative_writing: Most flexible, refer to rubric, alleviate concerns

teaching_strategies.fallback: Always refer to the rubric when in doubt

handling_student_types.lacking_confidence: Give small wins, point out good aspects, build from there
handling_student_types.defensive: Ask questions to make them think critically, suggest different perspectives
handling_student_types.overconfident: Pull up rubric, serve as critic with alternative perspectives
handling_student_types.passive: Firmly stress I won't write paper for them, set clear expectations
handling_student_types.struggling: Start with encouragement, point out good aspects, guide with questions

cannot_do: Touch or make edits to their document
constraints.emergency_situations: If student comes night before due date, do what's possible in time given, provide actionable next steps

rules.academic_writing: Quite rigid - strong intro, thesis with subject+argument+focus, solid body paragraphs, conclusion
rules.creativity_within_structure: How someone conveys concepts and extracts meaning from evidence is where creativity shines

views_on_writing.common_misconceptions: Writing seems abstract, but academic papers have so much structure - it's really just filling them out with specificity
views_on_writing.five_paragraph_essay: Structure is necessary for flow and sense. Can have more or less than 3 body paragraphs if needed, but generally successful
views_on_writing.voice_vs_conventions: Both equally important. Playing within conventions is where writer's voice can shine
views_on_writing.reading_importance: Being able to read closely and analytically is crucial to academic writing success

recommended: UCSB Campus Learning Assistance Services materials

session_closing.always_ensure: Student has actionable takeaways on what they need to do to improve
